se.suka.baldr.jbencode

Class AtomString

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.suka.baldr.jbencode.Atom
      • se.suka.baldr.jbencode.AtomString
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<AtomString>

    public final class AtomString
extends Atom
implements Comparable<AtomString>
    A byte string (a sequence of bytes, not necessarily characters) is encoded as <length>:<contents>. The length is encoded in base 10, like integers, but must be non-negative (zero is allowed); the contents are just the bytes that make up the string. The string "spam" would be encoded as 4:spam. The specification does not deal with encoding of characters outside the ASCII set; to mitigate this, some BitTorrent applications explicitly communicate the encoding (most commonly UTF-8) in various non-standard ways. This is identical to how netstrings work, except that netstrings additionally append a comma suffix after the byte sequence.
    Author:
    Graham Fairweather
    See Also:
    Bencode, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      AtomString()
      Initialises a newly created AtomString object so that it represents an empty character sequence.
      AtomString(AtomString anotherAtomstring)
      Initialises a newly created AtomString object so that it represents the same sequence of characters as the argument AtomString; in other words, the newly created AtomString is a copy of the argument AtomString.
      AtomString(byte[] value)
      Constructs a new AtomString by decoding the specified array of bytes using the specified StandardCharsets.US_ASCII.
      AtomString(String value)
      Initialises a newly created AtomString object so that it represents the same sequence of characters as the argument; in other words, the newly created AtomString is a copy of the argument string.

      • AtomString

        public AtomString(byte[] value)
        Constructs a new AtomString by decoding the specified array of bytes using the specified StandardCharsets.US_ASCII. The length of the new AtomString is a function of the charset, and hence may not be equal to the length of the byte array.

        The behavior of this constructor when the given bytes are not valid in the given charset is unspecified.

        Parameters:
        value - The bytes to be decoded into characters

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a hash code value for the object. This method is supported for the benefit of hash tables such as those provided by HashMap.

        The general contract of hashCode is:

        • Whenever it is invoked on the same object more than once during an execution of a Java application, the hashCode method must consistently return the same integer, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is modified. This integer need not remain consistent from one execution of an application to another execution of the same application.
        • If two objects are equal according to the equals(Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.
        • It is not required that if two objects are unequal according to the Object.equals(java.lang.Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce distinct integer results. However, the programmer should be aware that producing distinct integer results for unequal objects may improve the performance of hash tables.

        As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required by the Java™ programming language.)

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.
        See Also:
        Object.equals(java.lang.Object), System.identityHashCode(java.lang.Object)

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object obj)
        Compares this Atomstring to the specified object. The result is true if and only if the argument is not null and is a Atomstring object that represents the same sequence of characters as this object.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to compare this Atomstring against
        Returns:
        true if the given object represents a Atomstring equivalent to this string, false otherwise

      • getBytes

        public byte[] getBytes()
        Encodes this AtomString into a sequence of bytes using the given StandardCharsets.US_ASCII, storing the result into a new byte array.

        This method always replaces malformed-input and unmappable-character sequences with this charset's default replacement byte array.

        Returns:
        The resultant byte array

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<AtomString>
        Parameters:

        the value 0 if the argument AtomString is equal to this AtomString; a value less than 0 if this AtomString is lexicographically less than the AtomString argument; and a value greater than 0 if this AtomString is lexicographically greater than the AtomString argument.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified anotherAtomString is null
